'S-Adenosyl methionine' ('ademetionine', 'AdoMet', 'SAM', 'SAMe', 'SAM-e') is a
common cosubstrate involved in methyl group transfers. SAM was first discovered
in Italy by G. L. Cantoni in 1952. It is made from
adenosine triphosphate (ATP) and methionine by methionine adenosyltransferase
([http://www.expasy.org/enzyme/2.5.1.6 EC 2.5.1.6]). Transmethylation,
transsulfuration, and aminopropylation are the metabolic pathways that use SAM.
Although these anabolic reactions occur throughout the body, most SAM is
produced and consumed in the liver.

The methyl group (CH 3) attached to the methionine sulfur atom in SAM
is chemically reactive. This allows donation of this group to an acceptor
substrate in transmethylation reactions. More than 40 metabolic reactions
involve the transfer of a methyl group from SAM to various substrates, such as
nucleic acids, proteins, lipids and secondary metabolites.

In bacteria, SAM is bound by the SAM riboswitch, which regulates genes involved
in methionine or cysteine biosynthesis.
